The AI Chasm in biomedicine

Why do we fail to translate innovative ML results to clinical practice?

22 April 2025
Machine Learning
Biomedicine

Who am I?

Hi, I am Giovanni, a ML engineer working on biomedical applications of machine learning and AI. Creating pipelines to manipulate data and train models takes up most of my normal workdays. You can read more about it in the About Me page.

Why am I making this post?

I have been involved in biomedical ML for a few years now, and have been exposed both to amazing research works from talented researchers and to the harsher reality of what finds application in the real world to improve patient care.

Especially during the current hype cycle of "AI is going to take over all jobs," I think it is crucial to have a grounded discussion about the very real limitations of ML, as well as how we go about addressing them. Machine learning has a lot to offer to the biomedical field, but robust applications require extensive collaborations, the balancing of innovation and the protection of patients, the understanding of the complexities of data collection, and more. This post will serve as a personal reflection note on the topic, but I hope it can be of use to anybody else that finds this field of inquiry as important as I do.

The AI chasm

If you have spent any time doing ML research in the academic context, you will know full well that each author's novel method outperforms the previous models and that almost all papers claim impressive performance on the task analysed. This consistent narrative (of which I am guilty as well) is mostly shaped by the incentive structure within academia, that rewards positive results while neglecting negative outcomes, and that does not put any further requirements on scientific works after the paper is published.

Now consider the rapidly increasing number of publications within the field of machine learning each year

and, more specifically, the number of papers that involve biomedical applications of ML (this plot goes up to 2020, but the trend has only continued afterwards)

With this insane rate of research output, you would imagine that we would have ML-powered systems embedded in all sectors of healthcare, right?

The limited reach of ML in healthcare

The reality, unfortunately, is that the number of ML-based devices and solutions adopted in clinical practice are limited, both in number and field of application. Let us take a look, for example, at the list of ML-enabled medical devices approved by the FDA in the US, which is periodically updated. I downloaded the list of devices as last updated on 25/03/2025, which contained references for 1016 devices, and checked the field of application for each of them.

Not only is the total number or ML-enabled systems low, but we can also see that the fields of application with any significant presence are limited to just a few. Surely, a cause of this phenomenon is the considerable inertia of sectors such as healthcare, paired with an abundance of regulations that aim to protect patients. But ultimately, the major cause of the AI Chasm in biomedicine is that most models developed in silico simply do not show good performance in the real world. Why is that?

The causes of the AI Chasm

Several systematic reviews have analysed the performance of ML models in certain clinical settings, and identified some potential common factors to explain the poor performance.

Quite emblematic is the case of two studies that took into consideration a large number of prognostic models developed for Covid-19.

Roberts et al. [3], summarize their findings as

Our review finds that none of the models identified are of potential clinical use due to methodological flaws and/or underlying biases.

while Wynants et al. [4] examined 606 prognostic models, and found that

29 had low risk of bias, 32 had unclear risk of bias, and 545 had high risk of bias. The most common causes for high risk of bias were inadequate sample sizes (n=408, 67%) and inappropriate or incomplete evaluation of model performance (n=338, 56%).

Unfortunately, this phenomenon is not specific to Covid-19, but a more general issue in biomedical ML (and ML at large). Navarro et al. [5], for example, analyse 152 studies, and conclude that

Most studies on machine learning based prediction models show poor methodological quality and are at high risk of bias.

In general, the main causes appear to be a combination of the following:

  • Inadequate data quantity or quality
  • Poor evaluation strategies/methodologies
  • The lack of external validation (i.e. further confirmation beyond just having a test set)

The last one, in particular, is a challenge that is very typical of the biomedical field. Running additional experiments to confirm the performance of a model is generally resource-intensive, time-consuming, or straight-up unfeasible.

So what can we do about it?

This is the part that involves my opinions rather than objective facts. If there was an easy solution to this issue, then it would not really be a problem, no?

The most radical solution would require the restructuring of the incentive structure within academia. As long as researchers are evaluated on metrics such as the number of publications, dedicating your complete efforts to developing a long-running and robust project is going to be actively detrimental to your academic career. The difficulty of publishing negative results (which would be of great scientific value) only exacerbates the biases in the published literature. We have been aware of this kind of issue for a while now, but we are no closer to a good solution. In my opinion, changing the way researchers are evaluated and rewarded for their efforts will be crucial to protect and restore scientific integrity, and reduce the number of studies that oversell their results.

Barring deep structural changes to academic research, encouraging collaboration with domain experts could serve to stem the publication of invalid results. As a ML researcher, I had several conversations with medical or biology experts where they clearly explained why some approach/idea that I was considering would offer no real value. The knowledge that I lacked (and that they shared with me) prevented me from immediately identifying worthy problems to solve and actually interesting approaches to address them.

And finally, the development of good benchmarks could prove vital to correct the direction of efforts within academic research, and ensure that we are working to solve the right problems. The existence of the CASP competition, for example, was instrumental in all the developments that led to AlphaFold. Unfortunatly, creating high-quality benchmarks is really hard, and requires enormous efforts that are not always rewarded proportionally.

I will continue to read novel developments in biomedical ML with excitement, but I will always take them with a grain of salt until it is demonstrated that they can turn into something valuable in the real world.

References

  1. Krenn, Mario, et al. "Forecasting the future of artificial intelligence with machine learning-based link prediction in an exponentially growing knowledge network." Nature Machine Intelligence 5.11 (2023): 1326-1335.

  2. Mesk√≥, Bertalan, and Marton G√∂r√∂g. "A short guide for medical professionals in the era of artificial intelligence." NPJ digital medicine 3.1 (2020): 126.

  3. Roberts, Michael, et al. "Common pitfalls and recommendations for using machine learning to detect and prognosticate for COVID-19 using chest radiographs and CT scans." Nature Machine Intelligence 3.3 (2021): 199-217.

  4. Wynants, Laure, et al. "Prediction models for diagnosis and prognosis of covid-19: systematic review and critical appraisal." bmj 369 (2020).

  5. Navarro, Constanza L. Andaur, et al. "Risk of bias in studies on prediction models developed using supervised machine learning techniques: systematic review." bmj 375 (2021).
